snippet.title: Successful rapid prototyping with React Native - Perttu L√§hteenlahti
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Day Berlin Conference 2019
  
Check out the latest React Day Berlin news ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Summit Amsterdam ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

Perttu L√§hteenlahti

React Native is the best framework for rapid prototyping. In this lightning talk, I present a case study of how React Native was used to build three successful mobile prototypes, what tools we used to measure the effectiveness of those prototypes, and how React Native allowed us to test our product hypotheses faster

¬†

snippet.title: Sharing Code Between React and React Native: What Not to Share - Ben Ellerby
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Summit Amsterdam news ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

# Sharing Code Between React and React-Native: What Not to Share
# React Native Track

React and React Native allow a "learn once, write anywhere" paradigm. This is great because one tech team can build both your web app and native mobile experience. The problem is developers hate writing things twice. There have been a couple of efforts to build a unifying technology to write an application once and have it work on both web and native. Yet this is not always the best approach. There is value in only sharing your business and state logic; keeping your render code separate.

In this talk, Ben Elerby gives real examples from his work with MADE.COM, migrating their web and mobile application to React and React-Native with code sharing as a primary objective.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

snippet.title: From Native to React Native - Greg Ryzhov
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Day Berlin Conference 2019
  
Check out the latest React Day Berlin news ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Summit Amsterdam ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

Greg Ryzhov

Rewriting an app is an exciting process, but it comes with its drawbacks. In this talk, I‚Äôll focus on the challenges to expect when transitioning from native to React Native and how to avoid/overcome those challenges. I‚Äôll share learnings from my team‚Äôs first-hand experience and cover:
- Factors to consider when deciding to use React Native
- Organizational and technical challenges that can arise and how to deal with these challenges
- Expectations post-release.

¬†

snippet.title: Hooking Up A Conference In Real-Time With React Native & GraphQL - Nader Dabit
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Advanced London news ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Summit Amsterdam ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com/

# Hooking Up A Conference In Real-Time With React Native & GraphQL

"You‚Äôre starting a conference. You announce the conference, start planning the venue, getting sponsors, & fielding talks. Things start getting serious, & before you know it you‚Äôre overloaded with obligations. Oh, & you forgot: You also need a conference app!

You don‚Äôt just want any conference app; you want it to be fun, engaging, & a valuable addition to the attendees. How can you do this in the least amount of time?

In this talk, I‚Äôll show how you can rapidly prototype, build, & deploy your app using GraphQL, React Native, & AWS AppSync so you can spend your time worrying about more important things in life. In addition to what you‚Äôd expect from a conference app, we‚Äôll be adding live chat so attendees discuss talks & speakers can field questions & interact with them in real-time."

¬†

# React Native At Wix - Building an App for 150 Million Users
Ever wondered how to use microservices approach in a FED/mobile application? Hesitating to choose React Native for your big project? Omri's here to eliminate the school of thought that React Native is mostly for small mobile applications.

Omri Bruchim
Passionate about iOS & React Native, working mostly on infrastructure & mobile performance, organizer of React Native Talks meetups series.

For the past few years, I've been lucky enough to be part of scaling the Wix Mobile application and its team. Mostly focused on leading Mobile engineers working with our React Native app. My drive is working with talented people to create great products.

# React Native Track

While Animations can be created in React Native pretty easily, real world mobile apps require a combination of several layers of animations, gestures and micro interaction animations to make user experience stand out. Walk through the process from defining complex animation, to implementing it by going through all stages of animation creation process.

snippet.title: Offline-first in React Native: How to build great offline apps - Josh Warwick
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Advanced London news ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Summit Amsterdam ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com/

# Offline-first in React-Native: How to Lose Your Web Dev Reflexes and Build Great Offline Apps

React has helped us build web applications faster than ever, but turns out this doesn‚Äôt help build mobile apps. The main hurdle for web developers coming to mobile development (native apps with React native or PWAs) is handling offline capabilities.

Josh speaks firsthand about this learning curve, the pitfalls and realisations of doing this in production apps. As an architect developer at Theodo, he has seen developers struggle with this mindset switch on their projects over the past 2 years, and wants to share their learnings!

Josh speaks about:
- Optimistic UX updating
- Data persistence between app/server
- Offline mode (request queuing)
- Reconciling updates after this"

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

# Microinteractions and Animations in React Native
A microinteraction goal is to provide feedback based on the user‚Äôs action. This can help users visualize how the interface moves or behaves, even though it‚Äôs purely digital on a flat screen.

- What is a microinteraction
- The power of microinteraction
- How microinteractions work
- Basic microinteraction breakdown: Action, Reaction and Feedback
- Microinteractions examples in React Native

Dating app: https://github.com/catalinmiron/react-native-dating-app
Swipe cards: https://github.com/catalinmiron/react-native-swipe-cards-interaction
Photo walkthrough: https://github.com/catalinmiron/react-native-photo-walkthrough
Navigation transition: https://github.com/catalinmiron/react-native-nav-transition
Shopping list + details: https://github.com/catalinmiron/mobile-shopping-react-native

snippet.title: Practical Performance for React (Native) ‚Äì Anna DoubkovaÃÅ
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced Meetup https://www.meetup.com/React-Advanced/events/260425694/

There are quite a few theoretical concepts of writing good a React application, including popular functional programming approaches. However, few take into consideration the impacts these will have on performance of the application. In this talk you‚Äôll find out how some commonly used patterns have an adverse effect on the speed of your app, and how to avoid using them. We‚Äôll mainly explore UI and state management but we‚Äôll also dive into some native-specific issues and look at how to prevent them.

About Anna

Anna is a javascript developer who loves working with new technologies. Currently working at Hive, she does full-stack development to deliver a great end to end solution focused on user experience. She's a frequent speaker, runs workshops, and likes contributing to the community.

¬†

snippet.title: Full-stack React Native in the Era of Serverless Computing: Build an app in minutes - Nader Dabit
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Summit Amsterdam news ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

# Full-stack React Native in the Era of Serverless Computing
# React Native Track

With the emergence of more & more powerful & sophisticated managed services like Algolia, AWS AppSync, Cloudinary, Auth0, Amazon Rekognition & Firebase it's now completely possible for front-end engineers to build full-stack web & mobile applications while with almost no back-end code, relying on these services to do the heavy lifting for features like data layers, search, authentication, & authorization & using serverless glue functions to handle what‚Äôs left.

In this talk, Nader discusses this philosophy in depth, the options available from different service providers, & then showa how (live-code) to build a full-stack React Native application in just a few minutes by using React & AWS Amplify React Native to quickly build a real-world app complete with a GraphQL API, analytics, search, authentication & authorization.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

# Build your own Native Module

Sometimes an app needs to access a platform API and React Native doesn‚Äôt have a corresponding module yet. Maybe you want to reuse some existing Objective-C, Swift or C++ code without having to reimplement it in JavaScript, or write some high performance, multi-threaded code such as for image processing, a database, or any number of advanced extensions. In this talk you will learn how to do that and see a real-world example.

¬†

snippet.title: React Native: See the Past, the Present and the Future - Lorenzo Sciandra
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Advanced London news ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Summit Amsterdam ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com/

# React Native: the Past, the Present and the Future

React Native is now 4 years old. During this time, we‚Äôve observed more progression than ever before towards the vision of a cross-platform mobile solution. Even still, we have yet to realise its core mission of being as powerful as pure native. There have been many challenges that we‚Äôve faced head on as they‚Äôve surfaced. In overcoming them with the support of the community, we‚Äôve managed to establish React Native as a force that is now defining the future of the segment.

Explore this history-in-the-making before diving deeper into more technical subjects including the JSI & JSC upgrade, TurboModules & Fabric, and the CodeGen. With all the pieces of the puzzle in place and landing on master by end of the year, we are closer to reaching our original objective than ever before - while pushing the limits to a whole new level.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

snippet.title: Native Web Apps: Use React and WebAssembly to Rewrite Native Apps - Florian Rival
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Summit Amsterdam news ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

# Native Web Apps: React and WebAssembly to Rewrite Native Apps
# React Native Track

Can React and web technologies compete with native toolkits when it comes to making super complex, rich desktop apps? Can we go further and create better-than-native applications? ü§î Sounds like a good challenge!

This talk introduces how React, JavaScript and WebAssembly can be used to write new ambitious apps, or port existing ones - with real world examples! Florian shows how to leverage the React ecosystem to create performant applications: architecture, patterns, typing, useful open-source modules and tooling... and how to go one step further and provide a better user experience as well as a better developer experience.

These apps are not web apps, they are not native apps, they are hybrid 'Native Web Apps' and can provide the best of both worlds.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

# Make Your React Native Apps Accessible
# React Native Track

Did you know React Native has accessibility rules? In this talk, Ankita shows why accessibility matters, what those rules are, the accessibility standards your app falls into, common patterns to follow and how to get over your fear of voice-over.

By making our apps accessible, we provide a great experience for all our users. This talk is sure to leave you with actionable ways of making your apps accessible. Let‚Äôs make this native world a better and inclusive place for everyone.

¬†

snippet.title: Strangling Legacy with React Native: See its building & testing advantages - Adam Terlson
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

# Strangling Legacy with React Native

Building an app destined for production is a daunting task, especially to replace existing legacy apps available for download in the App and Play Store. Adam's team could have pursued a typical release strategy‚Äîinstead, they got creative with React Native.

They built a strangler-style architecture, a technique commonly reserved for web services, to release our greenfield React Native product user-by-user. The effect was some pretty unique and awesome advantages to how we built and tested our new app‚Äîbut software is never perfect.

¬†

snippet.title: Native Web Apps: Use React and WebAssembly to rewrite native apps - Florian Rival
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced Feb 2019 meetup https://www.meetup.com/React-Advanced/events/258924199/

## Native Web Apps: React and WebAssembly to Rewrite Native Apps
by Florian Rival (https://twitter.com/florianrival)

Can React and web technologies compete with native toolkits when it comes to making super complex, rich desktop apps? Can we go further and create better-than-native applications? ü§î Sounds like a good challenge!

This talk introduces how React, JavaScript and WebAssembly can be used to write new ambitious apps, or port existing ones - with real world examples! Florian shows how to leverage the React ecosystem to create performant applications: architecture, patterns, typing, useful open-source modules and tooling... and how to go one step further and provide a better user experience as well as a better developer experience.

These apps are not web apps, they are not native apps, they are hybrid 'Native Web Apps' and can provide the best of both worlds.

About Florian

Florian is a software engineer working at Facebook. He was an early adopter of React Native and open-sourced a few modules for it. He is the author of GDevelop, an open-source game making software based on React, WebAssembly, and JavaScript. He also made Lil BUB's Hello Earth, an 8-bit game starring the internet sensation cat, which available on desktop and mobile and powered by GDevelop and JavaScript.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

snippet.title: Building React Native: Take a look at the internals - Parashuram N
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Summit Amsterdam news ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

# Building React Native
# React Native Track

React Native is a great way to build native apps for iOS, Android and other mobile platforms. Take a look at the internals of React Native, and how code written in JavaScript can power a fully native mobile application. See the various parts of the current system like the bridge, the UI manager and the plugins. The talks also touches upon the rendering process and compare it to React‚Äôs rendering on the web.

See some of the new and exciting improvements (like Fabric, TurboModules and JSI) and how they significantly improve React Native. This talk stems from Parashuram's experiences as a web-developer newbie on the React Native team, and is an attempt to document his journey in comprehending the code base. At the end of the talk, the attendees will not only be able to build React Native apps, but also understands how it all works together.

¬†

#Continuous Workflow for a Large React Native App: Mobile At Wix - Rotem Mizrachi-Meidan and Shalom Yerushalmy

The Wix app is a large operation involving ~40 developers from 6 different product groups and a pretty big amount of features. Scaling this project requires code architecture that enables each module to be developed separately, but easily fit the big puzzle.
We‚Äôll discuss the way we do both unit and E2E testing, the way we scale our CI, the way we deploy and how we fix issues in production when they arise.
We‚Äôll also share our plans to how we‚Äôre going to scale our app and dev process to support 100 developers a year from today.

Rewriting an app is an exciting process, but it comes with its drawbacks. In this talk, I‚Äôll focus on the challenges to expect when transitioning from native to React Native and how to avoid/overcome those challenges. I‚Äôll share learnings from my team‚Äôs first-hand experience and cover:
- Factors to consider when deciding to use React Native
- Organizational and technical challenges that can arise and how to deal with these challenges
- Expectations post-release.

snippet.title: Network Layer in React Native - Alexey Kureev
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2018 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Summit Amsterdam news ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

#Network Layer in React Native

React Native provides us with a set of primitives for building mobile applications. A few of these can be aggregated into a "networking" layer that manages the transfer of data. This layer was designed to mimic an API we have in the Web, but despite all the similarities, it has its own *qualities* and caveats every good React Native developer should know about. In this talk I'll try to guide you through the networking layer in React Native and share some tips and tricks I've learned along the way.

¬†

# Microinteractions and Animations in React Native
A microinteraction goal is to provide feedback based on the user‚Äôs action. This can help users visualize how the interface moves or behaves, even though it‚Äôs purely digital on a flat screen.

- What is a microinteraction
- The power of microinteraction
- How microinteractions work
- Basic microinteraction breakdown: Action, Reaction and Feedback
- Microinteractions examples in React Native

Dating app: https://github.com/catalinmiron/react-native-dating-app

snippet.description:

# Offline-first in React-Native: How to Lose Your Web Dev Reflexes and Build Great Offline Apps

React has helped us build web applications faster than ever, but turns out this doesn‚Äôt help build mobile apps. The main hurdle for web developers coming to mobile development (native apps with React native or PWAs) is handling offline capabilities.

Josh speaks firsthand about this learning curve, the pitfalls and realisations of doing this in production apps. As an architect developer at Theodo, he has seen developers struggle with this mindset switch on their projects over the past 2 years, and wants to share their learnings!

Josh speaks about:
- Optimistic UX updating
- Data persistence between app/server
- Offline mode (request queuing)
- Reconciling updates after this"

snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced 2019 Conference ¬†

# Hooking Up A Conference In Real-Time With React Native & GraphQL

"You‚Äôre starting a conference. You announce the conference, start planning the venue, getting sponsors, & fielding talks. Things start getting serious, & before you know it you‚Äôre overloaded with obligations. Oh, & you forgot: You also need a conference app!

You don‚Äôt just want any conference app; you want it to be fun, engaging, & a valuable addition to the attendees. How can you do this in the least amount of time?

In this talk, I‚Äôll show how you can rapidly prototype, build, & deploy your app using GraphQL, React Native, & AWS AppSync so you can spend your time worrying about more important things in life. In addition to what you‚Äôd expect from a conference app, we‚Äôll be adding live chat so attendees discuss talks & speakers can field questions & interact with them in real-time."

snippet.title: Practical Performance for React (Native) ‚Äì Anna DoubkovaÃÅ
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced Meetup https://www.meetup.com/React-Advanced/events/260425694/

There are quite a few theoretical concepts of writing good a React application, including popular functional programming approaches. However, few take into consideration the impacts these will have on performance of the application. In this talk you‚Äôll find out how some commonly used patterns have an adverse effect on the speed of your app, and how to avoid using them. We‚Äôll mainly explore UI and state management but we‚Äôll also dive into some native-specific issues and look at how to prevent them.

About Anna

Anna is a javascript developer who loves working with new technologies. Currently working at Hive, she does full-stack development to deliver a great end to end solution focused on user experience. She's a frequent speaker, runs workshops, and likes contributing to the community.

¬†

# Build your own Native Module

Sometimes an app needs to access a platform API and React Native doesn‚Äôt have a corresponding module yet. Maybe you want to reuse some existing Objective-C, Swift or C++ code without having to reimplement it in JavaScript, or write some high performance, multi-threaded code such as for image processing, a database, or any number of advanced extensions. snippet.title: React Native: See the Past, the Present and the Future - Lorenzo Sciandra
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Advanced 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Advanced London news ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Summit Amsterdam ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com/

# React Native: the Past, the Present and the Future

React Native is now 4 years old. During this time, we‚Äôve observed more progression than ever before towards the vision of a cross-platform mobile solution. Even still, we have yet to realise its core mission of being as powerful as pure native. There have been many challenges that we‚Äôve faced head on as they‚Äôve surfaced. In overcoming them with the support of the community, we‚Äôve managed to establish React Native as a force that is now defining the future of the segment.

Explore this history-in-the-making before diving deeper into more technical subjects including the JSI & JSC upgrade, TurboModules & Fabric, and the CodeGen. With all the pieces of the puzzle in place and landing on master by end of the year, we are closer to reaching our original objective than ever before - while pushing the limits to a whole new level.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

snippet.title: Full-stack React Native in the Era of Serverless Computing: Build an app in minutes - Nader Dabit
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Summit Amsterdam news ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

# Full-stack React Native in the Era of Serverless Computing
# React Native Track

With the emergence of more & more powerful & sophisticated managed services like Algolia, AWS AppSync, Cloudinary, Auth0, Amazon Rekognition & Firebase it's now completely possible for front-end engineers to build full-stack web & mobile applications while with almost no back-end code, relying on these services to do the heavy lifting for features like data layers, search, authentication, & authorization & using serverless glue functions to handle what‚Äôs left.

In this talk, Nader discusses this philosophy in depth, the options available from different service providers, & then showa how (live-code) to build a full-stack React Native application in just a few minutes by using React & AWS Amplify React Native to quickly build a real-world app complete with a GraphQL API, analytics, search, authentication & authorization.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

snippet.title: Sharing Code Between React and React Native: What Not to Share - Ben Ellerby
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

Check out the latest React Summit Amsterdam news ‚Äì https://reactsummit.com

See other React conferences by GitNation
React Day Berlin ‚Äì https://reactday.berlin
React Advanced London ‚Äì https://reactadvanced.com

# Sharing Code Between React and React-Native: What Not to Share
# React Native Track

React and React Native allow a "learn once, write anywhere" paradigm. This is great because one tech team can build both your web app and native mobile experience. The problem is developers hate writing things twice. There have been a couple of efforts to build a unifying technology to write an application once and have it work on both web and native. Yet this is not always the best approach. There is value in only sharing your business and state logic; keeping your render code separate.

In this talk, Ben Elerby gives real examples from his work with MADE.COM, migrating their web and mobile application to React and React-Native with code sharing as a primary objective.

¬†
Subscribe to our channel to see more React (Native) talks: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsFrt8oKNYXGspSlX9u6uXw/

snippet.title: Native Web Apps: Use React and WebAssembly to Rewrite Native Apps - Florian Rival
snippet.description:
Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference ¬†

# Native Web Apps: React and WebAssembly to Rewrite Native Apps
# React Native Track

Can React and web technologies compete with native toolkits when it comes to making super complex, rich desktop apps? Can we go further and create better-than-native applications? ü§î Sounds like a good challenge!

This talk introduces how React, JavaScript and WebAssembly can be used to write new ambitious apps, or port existing ones - with real world examples! Florian shows how to leverage the React ecosystem to create performant applications: architecture, patterns, typing, useful open-source modules and tooling... and how to go one step further and provide a better user experience as well as a better developer experience.

These apps are not web apps, they are not native apps, they are hybrid 'Native Web Apps' and can provide the best of both worlds.

¬†

# Make Your React Native Apps Accessible
# React Native Track

Did you know React Native has accessibility rules? In this talk, Ankita shows why accessibility matters, what those rules are, the accessibility standards your app falls into, common patterns to follow and how to get over your fear of voice-over.

By making our apps accessible, we provide a great experience for all our users. This talk is sure to leave you with actionable ways of making your apps accessible. Let‚Äôs make this native world a better and inclusive place for everyone.
